All this one sees well done, with a musician’s brilliance,
by this Villager who was such an accomplished painter.

41. In sum, the height to which this Man has ascended
in depicting Reflection with expert art,
is not only renowned for his many Landscapes
but even the gold-tester Battus will applaud:
for in the Capital City I happened to see
by chance some Passion nocturnes,
where in the ground color of stone were numerous darks,
and the rays of light were incised in gold.
left-middleI saw these small pieces in Rome; they were painted on tablets of touchstone.

42. But why am I mentioning a foreigner?
I ought to consider Congiet,
Netherlandish-Italian Painter,
all of whose colors submitted to him
whenever he would set them to work.
Indeed, not one dared to disobey his Laws,
but had to do and become
as his ideas commanded.
left-middleCongiet was also clever with fire and light

43. And where the colors were at the limit
and unable to fulfill his intention,
he set out boldly with the son of Iapetus
to the chariot of the King of the Planets.
So that his fire and his lights might live,
he artfully employed gold
to make his fires swell and glow
and make his lights sparkle like stars.
left-middleCoignet made candlelight, which seems to burn, from raised gold bumps.

44. With colors he can marvelously burn
the city of Pluto, or destroy Troy;
he can have Judith displaying the head of Holofernes at night,
with Torches, Brands and Lanterns in the street,
and in the background a gathering of people.
He did this, for example, for the Lottery Prize,
commissioned by the Regents of the Insane Asylum in Amsterdam,
not to mention other pictures of his there.
left-middleExamples of some pieces by Congiet.

45. Then just as Pictura favors the Batavians
as much as Sicyonans in former times,
Nature came to the port of Haarlem
to throw everything in her bosom and bestow it
in the hearts of two of its residents.
One is truly a Painter: One of his,
in Amsterdam, is The Cave of Plato,
in which the Art is extraordinary.
left-middleAnother Example, of Plato’s Cave, by Cornelis Cornelisz. Van Haarlem, a piece in Amsterdam.

46. There one sees Reflections flashing everywhere
as a group of prisoners, lying in the dark,
seem to be battling, using Arguments,
about shadows of Figures cast by the light of a Lamp,
some, in freedom, see figures and shadows,
